content:
The Trump administration has limited the use of legal agreements to rein in rogue departments

 

ONE OF THE countless ways America has changed under President Donald Trump is that the federal government is much less interested in overseeing the work of local police.

The chief way it did this was by using “consent decrees”—binding agreements, brokered by a court, meant to force rogue local law enforcement agencies to undergo a series of reforms. The Obama administration frequently pursued such agreements, which were typically drawn up after lawsuits filed by the Department of Justice (DOJ) laid out a pattern of civil-rights abuses. They usually required police to undergo years of reforms, with monitors and federal judges looking over their shoulders—often at considerable cost.

The Obama administration signed consent decrees with 12 big-city police departments, among them Baltimore, Cleveland, New Orleans and Seattle. But Jeff Sessions, Trump’s first attorney-general, was open about his distaste for them. In one of his last acts before he stepped down Mr Sessions wrote a new policy for the DOJ that set new limits on their use and duration.

The Trump administration’s dim view of consent decrees is not surprising. The legislation enabling them was passed during Bill Clinton’s presidency; both he and Barack Obama were more enthusiastic about pursuing them than George W. Bush was. Republicans have tended to regard consent decrees as a manifestation of big government run amok.

But without consent decrees, it falls upon police to fix problems themselves. And how that plays out depends on the political landscape. In Chicago, following an investigation into the shooting of Laquan McDonald, an unarmed black teenager, in 2014, Mr Obama’s DOJ had been gearing up for a consent decree with Chicago police, when Mr Trump took office. The DOJ’s appetite for such a deal vanished and Illinois’s attorney-general, Lisa Madigan, stepped into the breach, playing the role typically filled by the feds and negotiating her own reform plan.

That wouldn’t happen everywhere. The city of New Iberia, Louisiana, offers an example of what can happen in the absence of action from the state attorney-general or DOJ. When, late in the Obama era, a federal investigation of the Iberia Parish sheriff exposed a pattern of deeply racist policing, no one expected the state attorney-general, Jeff Landry, to pursue such an agreement. An enthusiastic Trump supporter, Mr Landry has derided the Obama-era consent decree in New Orleans as a “hug-a-thug” document that hamstrings police. (Even left-leaning mayors who have embraced police reform have complained that consent decrees, while useful, are burdensome and expensive.)

The problems in New Iberia started at the top, according to the DoJ, with Louis Ackal, the sheriff. In 2016 it tried him on civil rights charges. Eventually, 11 ex-deputies pleaded guilty to planting drugs on fleeing suspects, beating scores without reason and writing up phony reports to cover their tracks. Most of the victims were black. But the sheriff was acquitted, and he came home to New Iberia, still the area’s most powerful lawman. By then, however, he had lost any enthusiasm he had for policing the city’s poor and heavily black West End. The result was chaos. Policing became reactive; officers responded when violence flared, but usually not before. Shootings and murders surged. When police tried to investigate, they were often met with stony silence by witnesses.

When Mr Ackal was acquitted, New Iberia, with 30,000 residents, was the largest city in Louisiana without its own police force. (The city had had one until 2004, when it decided to hire the sheriff, who primarily patrolled rural areas, for law enforcement.) In 2018, Freddie DeCourt, the newly elected mayor, launched the New Iberia Police Department. The early signs are encouraging. Police officials are trying to rebuild trust, and they have taken a hard line toward officers accused of past misconduct.

The experiment is still young, of course, and it is too early to call it a success. It is yet to be seen what will happen when communities with dysfunctional police departments choose not to tackle the problem themselves. Meanwhile, consent decrees are unlikely to be used by the DOJ again any time soon. Earlier this month, during his confirmation hearings in the Senate, William Barr, Mr Trump’s new choice for attorney-general, said he agreed with Mr Sessions’s decision to limit them.

很清楚，范尼梅和弗雷德马做的每一件事情都是因为追求利润---毕竟，他们都是私营企业。
Currently, most mortgages in the US flow through Fannie or , and nearly half of all outstanding mortgage debt is linked to them in some way.
现在，美国的大多数抵押贷款都流经房地美或房利美，在未偿付抵押贷款中，一半都与他们发生过某种关联。

eg2: Responsiveness can also be a double-edged sword, either keeping unelected intelligence officials from running  or making them run in too many directions at once.

An Indian inventor has created a device to stop rampaging elephants in their tracks, amid concern about human injuries and deaths when they run , his company said last week.
印度某公司上周表示，该公司一名发明家已设计出一款装置，可以让抓狂乱冲的大象止步，减少人类受伤或丧生的机率。

他称硕士学位的泛滥迹象是“文凭获得走向狂乱。”

他们违犯了第 119 条。

泄密；背信
a breach of security(= when sth that is normally protected is no longer secure)

他们从铁丝网上的一个缺口逃走了。

eg2: Although you don't need a burdensome process to achieve quality, you do need an organization mindset that focuses on quality, and that must be driven by top management.

Many businesses have asserted that the reporting requirement is a first step toward burdensome and needless government regulation.

ex: adj. 相当大的；重要的，值得考虑的
eg2: He owns considerable real estate.
他拥有相当可观的房地产。
He will stand to get a  profit through the speculations in lands.
他在地产投机生意上必定会赚相当可观的一笔钱。
Impeding means that the persona could use the product, but only with considerable effort.
阻碍意味着角色可以使用产品，但只有付出相当大的努力。

ex: adj. 无数的；数不尽的
eg2: In the war countless innocent people lost their lives.
在这场战争中无数无辜的人丧失了性命。
The inscription on the stone tablet has been rubbed away by the hands of countless tourists over the centuries.
石碑上的碑文经过几个世纪被无数游客的手磨光了。
I know, because He’s done it for us, and countless others.
我知道，因为他已经治愈了我，还有无数其他人。

wp.decree nisi: 离婚暂准判令;法院发生暂准令;暂准判令;离婚暂准令

eg2: The final decree dissolved their marriage.
最后的判决解除了他们的婚姻关系。
When a graphic element was changed by law or decree it was chronicled in this document.
当一个图形元素为法律和法令所改变，就在这份档案里按时间储存。
It will be 'a decree to take the gold sector, ' which still remains in the hands of a 'mafia and smugglers, ' he said.
查韦斯说，这将是一项接管黄金产业的法令。 这一产业目前仍在黑手党和走私贩的控制下。

ex: n. 部；部门；系；科；局
eg2: The  offers four specialities.
这个系有四个专业。
This room has been set aside for the department files.
这个房间已被用来存放本部门的案卷。
The manager deputed the running of the  to his secretary.
经理把部门的管理工作委托给他秘书了。

ex: v. 嘲笑；愚弄；揶揄

ex: n. 厌恶；讨厌

vi. 不喜欢
eg2: If so, Singapore’s government will have another industrial-policy triumph to boast about—assuming, that is, that it can overcome its official  for saying anything positive about gambling.
如果是这样，新加坡政府将有另一次的工业政策的胜利来吹嘘，假设，那就是，它可以克服人们对赌博持有积极态度的厌恶。
If you have a solemn distaste for it, you might want to switch employers.
如果你对它有着严重的厌恶感，那么你可能要换雇主了。

eg2: And they can help us understand more about the frequency, intensity and duration of storms.
它能帮助我们更好的了解暴风雨天气的频率、强度和持续时间。
The  of the service can be one hour or more, so you can use it to generate notices while you are in a meeting.
该服务的持续时间可以是一个小时或更长时间，因此您可以在开会时使用该服务来生成通知。
Of course, for the project to have acceptable risk, this must be done for each of the tasks, leading to almost doubling the .
当然，对于拥有可接受的风险的项目来说，必须对每个任务都这样做，这将导致几乎将持续时间加倍。

这个流程关心的是策略的设计和执行。
There is no effective enforcement mechanism and remedies for workers at all.
根本不存在有效地执行机制和对工人的补救措施。
Each policy might require one or more enforcement points in the implementation.
在实施中每个策略可能需要一个或更多的实施点。

ex: n. 热情；热忱；热心；热衷的事物
网络 热诚；狂热；积极性
eg2: I can't say I share your enthusiasm for the idea.
我可不像你那样，对这个想法那样热心。
He had a real enthusiasm for the work.
他的确热衷于这项工作。
She never lost her enthusiasm for teaching.
她从未失去过教书的热忱。
The news was greeted with a lack of enthusiasm by those at the meeting.
与会者对这消息未表现出多少兴趣。
‘I don't mind,’ she said, without much enthusiasm.
“我不在乎。”她不冷不热地说。
full of enthusiasm
充满热情

ex: adj. 热情的；热心的；狂热的
eg2: Here the crowd was thickest and most .
这里的人群最密集， 热情也最高。
And not only that, people just like to be around  people in general.
不仅仅如此，总体来说，人都比较倾向于与热情的人往来。
people also love what they do, regardless of money or title or power.
热心的人同样热爱他们所做的，而不管金钱、头衔或者权威。

wp.AEAuto Expose: 自动曝光效果;主动曝光结果
wp.expose to: 使曝光;暴露;暴露于;使暴露

ex: vt. 揭露，揭发；使曝光；显示
eg2: The corrupt official bought off those who might expose him.
那名接受贿赂的官员收买了那些可能会揭发他的人。
And I think that desire to  current events for what they are motivates us.
我认为是那种想报道现在正在发生的事情的愿望激励了我们 。
Her then boss reportedly threatened her if she quit, he would expose her on the Internet.
据说她当时的老板威胁她，如果退出的话他将在网络上曝光她。

ex: n. 照明弹；（短暂的）旺火；（摇曳的）光；（闪耀的）火光
v. 加剧；（短暂）烧旺；（摇曳着）燃烧；（火光）闪耀
网络 闪光；耀斑；闪烁
eg2: The match flared and went out.
火柴闪亮了一下就熄了。
The fire flared into life.
火旺了起来。
Colour flared in her cheeks.
她两颊泛起了红晕。
Violence flared when the police moved in.
警察逼近时爆发了暴力行为。
Tempers flared towards the end of the meeting.
会议快结束时群情激愤。
‘You should have told me!’ she flared at him.
“你应该告诉我的！”她气冲冲地对他说。
The sleeves are tight to the elbow, then flare out.
袖子在肘部收紧，接着逐渐展开。
The horse backed away, its nostrils flaring with fear.
马向后惊退，吓得鼻翼扇动。
The flare of the match lit up his face.
火柴的光照亮了他的脸。
The ship sent up distress flares to attract the attention of the coastguard.
这艘船点起了遇险信号以引起海岸警卫队的注意。
a skirt with a slight flare
下摆略张的裙子
a pair of flares
一条喇叭裤
